wordpressPost.title: employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup: 12/5/2014
wordpressPost.content:
The WeSpire Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup aggregates the top articles from around the industry so that you can stay up-to-date on the state of employee engagement in CSR and sustainability on the go.

The Yawn Known as HR Gamification

Research indicates that more businesses are using gamification to increase engagement with consumers, but is HR taking full advantage of this technology? Gamification could be harnessed during recruitment and corporate learning/training programs. Using game mechanics, HR can more efficiently credential and track employees’something the industry could benefit from. Best quote of the week: All work and no play makes for disengaged workers.

Two Vital Steps for Fixing Your Employee Engagement Problem

Improving employee engagement is easier said than done, but starting by asking basic questions can help. This author suggests to first, focus on purpose: Why does your company and employees do what they do? Second, connect everyone to the bottom line: How does everyone’s job affect sales or increased profit? When everyone is unified in what they do, why they do it, and how it affects the company, employees begin thinking like owners.

Keeping Down with the Joneses: How You’re Being Manipulated To Save The Environment

New research shows that the fear-based approaches to environmental change from the last 10 years are backfiring and that people care more about keeping up with their peers. Software company, Opower, uses the power of social influence and behavioral science to decrease energy use by providing neighborhood-targeted consumption reports to residents. The best part? Opower customers have collectively saved nearly 9B pounds of carbon dioxide and 5.2B killowatts of energy.

How to Find Your Formula for Employee Engagement

Knowing that employee engagement is not a ‘one-size-fits-all’ solution, this article provides a roadmap for how to get started. The framework builds off of experience from TD Bank, and breaks down the journey into 3 critical steps: [1] Know your Destination, Identify Your Mile Markers, [2] Get Your Passengers onto the Bus, and [3] Recruit New Passengers.

In the Future, Companies Will Survive Only if They Help Solve Big Social Problems

This article predicts 2015 as the critical year where business begins a long-term transition to focus on solving the world’s social issues. To ensure future success, businesses will have to shift their thinking and actions, moving from traditional philanthropy to achieving bold social goals like We’re going to eliminate youth homelessness by 2025.’
